summary: Male breast cancer (MBC) is a cancer that originates in the breasts of males. It accounts for less than 1% of new breast cancer cases worldwide. Knowledge of MBC is less extensive than for female breast cancer due to its lower incidence and exclusion from large-scale studies. Many evaluation and treatment strategies are adopted from female breast cancer, but MBC has distinct features.
causes: High estrogen levels relative to androgen levels
Consumption of hormonal drugs for gender reassignment therapy
risk_factors: Radiation exposure to the chest or entire body
Long-term exposure to high temperatures (e.g., blast furnaces, steel works, rolling mills)
Testicular dysfunction (e.g., undescended testes, congenital inguinal hernia, orchitis)
Gynecomastia (historically considered, but not established in recent work)
symptoms: Skin lesion such as an ulcer
Enlargement or masses in axillary lymph nodes (indicating metastasis)
diagnosis: Physical examination (measuring lump size, checking lymph nodes)
Medical imaging (ultrasonography, mammography, CT scans, magnetic resonance imaging, positron-emission tomography, scintimammography, single-photon emission computed tomography)
Testing for estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR), androgen receptor (AR), and HER2/neu receptor expression
subtypes: Papillary carcinomas of the breast (in situ, encapsulated, solid-papillary, invasive)
Invasive cribriform carcinoma of the breast
